title: Populations affect correlations
tweetText:
What's interesting to me ab this chart that @Codie_Sanchez shared was how different the correlations can vary depending on your culture. eg. Russian/English speakers are much better at "being left alone" (only a -0.2 r to life satisfaction) vs Estonian-speakers (a -0.6 r).

Full study: https://osf.io/preprints/osf/cd5kt‚Ä¶

title: Discovered MrBeast
tweetText:
Watched my first MrBeast video last night (the one where he gets together 50 YouTubers to compete for $1M). Afterwards, I watched three more vids (the laser challenge + "protect yacht" + "protect Lamborghini"). The spectacle of his videos is undeniable. He is 26yo & worth $500M. Incredibly impressive.

Read up more on his Wikipedia page. He began posting YT vids when he was 13yo. Very inspiring story.

title: Writing fiction: story & narrative
tweetText: Writing fiction is tough bc you need to figure out both the story & the narrative. Whereas, w/ writing non-fiction, the story already exists, so you're really just crafting the narrative: ie. trying to decide what scenes to include, what ppl & events to focus on, etc. But w/ writing fiction, you need to first create the clay itself before you can sculpt it.

title: Bad Therapy
tweetText: Not all therapy is good. In fact, a while back, there was that "Bad Therapy" book making the rounds that discussed this. Just repeatedly talking ab your problems isn't always healthy. Instead, *doing things* (that one viral tweet ab "dancing being the best antidepressant" comes to mind) will actually help you way more than an endless amount of talk therapy ever could.

title: Regularly show up to develop a consistent habit
tweetText:
Can't remember where I first read this, but if you're trying to build a new habit, the best first step is to simply regularly show up at a consistent time & place. Doesn't matter if you actually do the thing in the beginning (coding, writing, exercising, etc). But initially, just show up regularly & consistently.

Once you train your body to routinely be in a specific place at a specific time for a specific duration each day, the rest will follow.

title: Installed last two remaining blinds from Home Depot

I finally installed the last two remaining blinds in my home today. These were tasks on The List! I've literally procrastinated for nine months but today was finally the day!! "üí™"

Whatever you've been putting off, just do it. One task every day, big or small. It'll set you free!!

It‚Äôs an unfortunate thing, but it turns out that the perfect state of mind to edit your own novel is two years after it‚Äôs published, ten minutes before you go on stage at a literary festival."  ‚Äî @ZadieSmith

Starting tmr, I'm going to knock exactly one item off the list every day this next week.

You should too. Who's with me?! Let's do it together!"üí™"

title: Boxer & Biden - Animal Farm
tweetText:
Boxer. In that scene towards the end where he's being carted away to the slaughterhouse. That's what I kept thinking of when I watched the debate clips last week. Honestly, I blame Biden's team maybe more than I even fault Biden. Ppl around him are not telling him what he needs to hear. And I cannot blame the man for fighting. He's been a public servant just ab his entire adult life. He's a fighter; not a quitter. Never giving up & always trying his best is just who he is. He doesn't know how to quit.

In any case, this is why you should read the classics. They stay in your head long after you've finished them and give you great shorthand & references when communicating w/ others. It's basically having a whole other shared vernacular w/ ppl who share your preferences in books!

title: ‚ÄúThe whole thing was very clinical. Reduced to its technical essence, it was a problem of resource management‚Äù
tweetText: Great fiction ‚Äîlike, truly great, the kind you remember your whole life‚Äî have passages you remember long after you've closed the cover. They resonate in a way deep & personal in that particular season of life you're in when you'd first read it (and perhaps even now), bc they capture & express something so real in your own life that you're feeling intimately. And then years later, like an old friend, they revisit you, entirely randomly, apropos of nothing, from time to time in your mind's eye. That is great fiction.

title: Fiction Writing as a Bottom-Up Process
tweetText: Idk how other ppl write fiction. But what I've learned ab (trying) to write fiction is that I cannot force it. I may feel like I have some brilliant top-down idea of how I wish for the story to go. But whenever I try to force it, things just don't work. Instead, for me it's become a bottom-up process where I create the "clay" on my first pass. And then I use top-down processes later in my second & subsequent passes to mold that clay & stich together what works. Again, maybe there's a better way to do it. But I haven't found it.

title: Playing Life On Hard Mode (a life without children)
tweetText:
Playing Life on Hard Mode

I used to think that not having kids & being childfree was playing life on "easy mode". And it is, in certain ways.

But as I've gotten older, I've also realized that being childfree is also akin to playing life on hard mode, in a few but important ways.

When you have kids, the north star is clear. There's a clear priority for your life. And the structure's also clear. (Or at least, more clear.) For most ppl, everything is done in service of your family, with your kids being first. How much money you need to make. What kind of work you need to do to make that money. How much you need to save. All these kinds of constraints do tie you down, but they also give form & purpose to your life. They keep you grounded & tethered to reality.

Every day, if you have kids, by simply making it through the day, you have contributed to your children's development. You've answered their questions, fed them, and have helped them grow. Every day, even if you're purely moving through the world in a reactive mode, you've done something meaningful w/ your life. (Or at least, moved the needle forward in some small way. At very minimum, you're at least contributing to the future tax base of your country. You are contributing to a collective project, larger than yourself!)

But in the absence of children being the forcing function, childfree ppl need to be disciplined ab how they structure their life. Not for one day, one week, or one year. But for your entire life. Also, you have to make sure you're actually doing something w/ your life. When you're childless, it's easy to squander entire days without contributing anything to anyone.

title: Money Buys Happiness with no Plateau for 80% of people - Updated 2023 Study
tweetText:
https://forbes.com/sites/johnjennings/2024/02/12/money-buys-happiness-after-all/‚Ä¶

I am in the group of ppl for whom increasing money buys increasing happiness with no plateau. A new study in 2023 by Kahneman/Killingsworth found that 80% of ppl are in this "no plateau" group.

I know a lot of ppl who still cite the older 2010 Kahneman/Deaton study though that concluded that there was a plateau ‚Äî time to update on new data!!

title: Chinese Brand Supremacy?
tweetText:
Chinese Brand Supremacy?

Maybe it was inevitable, but I've noticed an increasing number of my personal devices switch over to Chinese brands. First was my laptop yrs ago (Lenovo from Dell). Then my scooter (NIU). And now I'm considering an Open (OnePlus from Samsung). For yrs, everything was made in China (eg. your fancy MacBook) but then other companies just slapped their logo over it. But now I think China's finally getting into the international market w/ their own premium Chinese brands. (The other obvious example here is TikTok. But not me! Still on X. "üôÇ")

As of now though, I do still use:
- Microsoft (US) - keyboard
- Logitech (Swiss) - mouse
- Bose (US) - headphones

It's just a bit of cognitive dissonance for me bc for years I've never associated Chinese brands with quality (w/ the exception of Lenovo. And honestly, that's just bc I use ThinkPad, which they'd acquired from IBM). To me, quality always meant American, Japanese, or Korean. Or maybe a European country (for cars, for example). But I think that's changing now. Chinese brands are ascendant! A whole new generation of Americans are going to grow up regularly using TikTok, Shein, and Temu, thinking that Chinese companies are the cream of the crop. (And if American car companies weren't protected by US tariffs, BYD would likely be a huge Tesla competitor, I think.)

Am curious though‚Äî what brands are ppl using nowadays? Do you see a shift towards Chinese ones?

title: Scooter Speeds: European Mode vs American Mode
tweetText:
My scooter has been in "European Mode" which means it was capped at 25 kph (15 mph). (That is apparently the speed restriction by law over there.) Today, a firmware update finally released that allows it to now go 32 kph (20 mph). American mode! There's a huge difference!

Maybe this is confirmation bias, but it honestly feels like a through line to me that everything is so much more regulated in Europe: GDPR, no AC at the Olympics, and scooter max speeds. I'm happy to be proved wrong though!

Question: what is something that Europe is more laissez-faire ab, compared to America? "ü§î"

title: Each Person's Unique Gradient Descent to Happiness
tweetText: Each and every person has their own unique gradient descent to happiness. Find it and the world is yours.

title: 'Why Men Are 'Rawdogging' Flights' | GQ
tweetText:
It's interesting to me how as a child & younger person, I really enjoyed being active & doing things. But then as an adult, I've noticed that I increasingly enjoy resting more if I have free time. Rather than mindlessly watch YouTube or go out just for the sake of going out, I increasingly prefer staying inside & collecting my thoughts or just letting my mind go blank altogether. Also, when I work I now listen to music less & less as well.

I used to think that quiet time & space was a time to fill with activity. But now my powers of concentration need to be more... conserved & focused? It's almost as if any activity at all depletes me in some way. Even "passive" activities like listening to music.

I can't speak for other men, but I wonder if this is a new trend that's happening. "ü§î"

title: 'Being selfish' is a legitimate motivation
tweetText:
Great read! Personally, I feel it's fine (& even good) for ppl to have kids for selfish reasons. On the flip side, plenty of ppl also choose to be childfree, also for selfish reasons.

Being selfish simply means "being concerned chiefly with one's own personal profit or pleasure". I respect ppl who acknowledge their own motivations honestly & authentically.

title: Say no to 'Delayed Gratification'
tweetText:
Sometimes if you're floundering, stop doing what you feel you should be doing & just instead do what you want to do. As I've gotten older, I increasingly believe less & less in "the marshmallow test".

Saying no to "delayed gratification" has been one of my biggest unlocks.

title: Create forcing functions; a life w/o urgency goes nowhere

In the absence of children, it's important to create forcing functions for yourself. Constraints is what makes everything go. Routine is your friend.

A life without urgency is a life that goes nowhere.

title: Where are the childfree people?
tweetText: On X, I often see many tweets extolling raising children. Which is great! What I see less of though are tweets from ppl who are childless. As someone older who's childless, I've always wondered: where are the ppl going through adult life w/o children? If anyone else is curious ab what a childfree adult life is like, pls lmk. It's something I've been considering writing ab, if there are any ppl out there who are also keen ab the subject.
